steps.title: Yawn or chew gum to open your eustachian tubes.
steps.content: Yawn or chew gum to open your eustachian tubes. Sometimes when your ears are clogged, the remedy is as simple as yawning, which can equalize the pressure in your ears. Or, pop a piece of sugar-free gum in your mouth and chew it for a few minutes. These simple methods can get your ears to pop, providing immediate relief. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You will know when your ears pop when the pressure built up inside them releases and you can hear again.

steps.title: Try the Toynbee maneuver to unclog your ears.
steps.content: Try the Toynbee maneuver to unclog your ears. The Toynbee maneuver helps relieve pressure in your middle ear, eliminating the “clog” that causes discomfort. Take a sip of water, but don’t swallow it yet. Keep your mouth closed and use your fingers to gently hold your nostrils closed. Then, swallow the water. You can repeat this maneuver up to 5 times.

steps.title: Do the valsalva maneuver to relieve pressure.
steps.content: Do the valsalva maneuver to relieve pressure. Pinch your nose to plug your nostrils and keep your mouth shut. Exhale gently like you are trying to breathe out of your nose. Resist the urge to blow too hard as this could hurt or damage your eardrum. There may be a small pop sound associated with the relief of pressure when using this remedy, but it should not be accompanied by any pain. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Not only is this good for blockage due to colds , it's also very handy for pilots, airline passengers, and divers.

steps.title: Use steam to thin your earwax.
steps.content: Use steam to thin your earwax. Heat a pot of water to boiling, then transfer the water to a heat-safe bowl. Lean over the bowl so your face is above the steam and use a towel or cloth to create a “tent” over your head and the bowl. Breathe in the steam for as long as desired. The pressure in your ears should decrease as the mucus and earwax in your ears thins out due to the steam. [3] X Research source Use a clean cloth to wipe away any earwax that leaks out of your ear canal. Feel free to add a few drops of essential oils, like lavender or tea tree, to the hot water.

steps.title: Apply a warm compress to drain the fluid in your ear.
steps.content: Apply a warm compress to drain the fluid in your ear. Take a clean washcloth and run it under hot water. Squeeze out the excess water, then place the washcloth on the clogged ear. Leave it there for up to 10 minutes and lie on the side of your affected ear so the fluid in your ear has time to drain out. Repeat as often as necessary. [4] X Research source Simply use the washcloth to wipe up any excess wax that comes out of your ear.

steps.title: Dry the fluid in your ear with a mixture of a vinegar and water.
steps.content: Dry the fluid in your ear with a mixture of a vinegar and water. Mix a solution that is 1 part vinegar to 4 parts water. Lean your head sideways and use a dropper to put a few drops of the solution in your ear. Keep your head tilted and allow the solution to settle in for about 5 minutes. [5] X Research source To keep it from spilling out, place a cotton ball in your ear before raising your head. If both ears need attention, repeat the process with the other ear.

steps.title: Soften your earwax with a few drops of oil.
steps.content: Soften your earwax with a few drops of oil. Tilt your head so the affected ear is facing upward. Use a dropper to put a few drops of warm (not hot) olive oil or mineral oil into your ear. Keep the head in the same position for about 5 minutes. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source After 5 minutes, lean your head upright and wipe away any oil and wax that exit the ear canal with a clean cloth. Repeat on the other side, if necessary.

steps.title: Take a decongestant if manual methods don’t work.
steps.content: Take a decongestant if manual methods don’t work. Nasal decongestants can help clear the sinuses, and return your hearing to some semblance of normalcy. Follow the instructions on the label, and avoid taking the decongestant for more than 3 days in a row. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Use a nasal spray with antihistamine if you have allergies.
steps.content: Use a nasal spray with antihistamine if you have allergies. In the event your sinus blockage is caused by allergies, an antihistamine may be just the thing you need. Look for a nasal spray containing antihistamine at your local drugstore, and use it according to the directions on the package. steps.title: See a healthcare provider if the issue persists.
steps.content: See a healthcare provider if the issue persists. If your ear pain is severe or lasts more than a few days, see your healthcare provider immediately. [9] X Expert Source Payam Daneshrad, MD Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 30 September 2020. They may prescribe medications such as topical nasal steroids, or help you explore other treatment options depending on the cause of your pain.
